awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:   Rapid and Pervasive Mitochondrial Heteroplasmy with Recombination in a Remerging Ectoparasite
awd_abstract_narration:
Mitochondria are parts of cells that have their own DNA, as well as a fundamental role in metabolism.  They are essential for animal life. With advances in DNA sequencing it has recently been shown that some individuals may possess multiple, distinct lineages of mitochondria in their cells.  This suggests that the presence of multiple types of mitochondria, a condition known as heteroplasmy, may be an integral part of the evolution of many species.  This finding is very surprising, because mitochondria, almost always are inherited from the mother only, and in humans, heteroplasmy has been linked to severe genetic disease. From an evolutionary perspective, the presence of more than one type of mitochondria in an individual may have an important function in generating genetic diversity.  It is likely that the presence of multiple types of mitochondria presents opportunities to exchange genes between different mitochondrial lineages. Despite growing recognition of the potential significance of heteroplasmy, this aspect of animal evolution remains poorly understood. This project aims to address key questions relating to how heteroplasmy is generated, how long it can be maintained, and whether genes are exchanged between mitochondrial lineages. The bed bug will be used as a model species for these studies because it exhibits unusually high levels of heteroplasmy. Experiments to resolve these questions have the potential to fundamentally change how we look at genetic inheritance of mitochondrial DNA in animals. The project will include training of undergraduate and post-doctoral scholars, the establishment of a collaborative network of researchers and pest control operators, and public outreach in both Oklahoma and North Carolina. Furthermore, given that the bed bug is a significant public health concern, establishing it as a model system will continue to bring them to public attention, reinforcing awareness of the species.

While uniparental inheritance appears to predominate in the animal kingdom, the growing evidence of heteroplasmy through paternal leakage and compelling recent evidence of mtDNA recombination, underscores that while we have developed a great understanding of mitochondrial function and evolution, our understanding of mitochondrial inheritance is far from complete. The bed bug, Cimex lectularius, is an ectoparasite that has seen an unprecedented resurgence in recent years. Studies have revealed that it exhibits high levels of mtDNA heteroplasmy, which is both pervasive and rapidly generated. Furthermore, mtDNA recombination appears common. Given the suitability and tractability of this species as a model system, this study will: (1) Address how intra- and inter-population genetic characteristics correlate with rates of heteroplasmy; (2) Investigate the degree to which mitogenomic divergence and mitonuclear interactions affect the rate of paternal leakage; (3) Empirically and theoretically examine heteroplasmy decay in a species where it is common and pervasive and for which genetic drift vs. selection may be evaluated; and (4) Take a complete mitogenomic approach to investigate recombination and the presence of recombination hotspots. Due to the high rate of leakage and recombination seen in the bed bug in concert with recent advances in DNA sequencing technology and analytical methods, this system offers a unique opportunity to address this hotly debated and evolutionarily consequential question.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit:

For most species mitochondrial DNA is maternally inherited, and thus is passed from mother to offspring as a single haplotype, termed homoplasmy. In recent years it has emerged that for some species, individuals may possess multiple distinct haplotypes, termed heteroplasmy. The origin of these variant mitogenomes may be through random mutations, the inheritance of multiple mtDNA lineages from the mother, or paternal leakage. In the latter, sperm mitochondrial DNA evades the mechanisms through which it is normally eliminated; thus, it is passed from sperm to egg, ultimately proliferating in the resulting offspring. The consequences of this are far reaching. This includes a potential reduction in fitness due to disruptions in mito-nuclear interactions. At the evolutionary level, the presence of multiple mitochondrial haplotypes will lead to erroneous phylogenetic, phylogeographic, and population genetic inference. Heteroplasmy also creates the opportunity for mitochondrial recombination, where DNA is exchanged among variant haplotypes. This has the potential to be detrimental, leading to mito-nuclear disruption, or beneficial, if the recombinant haplotypes have enhanced fitness under specific scenarios or if recombination eliminates deleterious mutations. The latter will slow the accumulation of irreversible deleterious mutations that will lead to population extinction, thus, eliminating Muller’s Ratchet. Despite evidence supporting heteroplasmy, and in rare instances recombination, our understanding of these processes is still in its infancy. As such, research into the dynamics of heteroplasmy, paternal leakage, and recombination, would fundamentally advance our understanding of mitochondrial evolution. The bed bug, Cimex lectularius, appears to be an ideal model system with which to study these evolutionary processes. Specifically, heteroplasmy appears both common and geographically widespread, existing in both ancestral and derived lineages. Furthermore, laboratory crosses between divergent haplotypes results in the production of heteroplasmic offspring, supporting paternal leakage, and those exhibiting evidence of recombination. At the time this award was funded, two reference genomes existed, and no evidence of nuclear mitochondrial insertions were found.

Using the bed bug as a model system, this project sought to (1) Evaluate the population characteristics that influence heteroplasmy, by correlating the occurrence and frequency of heteroplasmy with intrapopulation mitochondrial DNA diversity; (2) Determine whether the frequency of heteroplasmy was influenced by the level of mitochondrial DNA divergence among individuals and mitochondrial-nuclear interactions through selective lab crosses across a range of mitogenomic divergence; (3) Examine the dynamics of heteroplasmy transmission from mother to offspring and its potential decay over time; and (4) Examine recombination hot spots in the bed bug mitochondrial genome.

This research was impacted by several hurdles. First, the isolation of the mitogenome proved difficult using the proposed methods. Namely, 1) the digestion of linear DNA that should leave circular mitochondrial DNA for sequencing, routinely failed for bed bugs, but not for other invertebrates used as controls; and 2) the analyses of newly generated whole genome sequences failed to yield circular genomes. This was overcome through the development of a ddRADseq method that was assumed to target the mitochondrial genome, resulting in the identification of heteroplasmy in multiple mtDNA genes. Alignment of 24 whole genome sequences to the published mitogenome confirmed heteroplasmy is evident in all mitochondrial genes, with an abundance of variants in the cytochrome oxidase gene in particular. Second, and most impactful, a newly generated chromosome-level genome identified evidence of significant nuclear insertions of mitochondrial DNA. This latter finding has the potential to impact all Specific Aims of this project. This is being investigating further, prior to finalizing data analysis for Aims 1 through 4.

 

Broader Impacts:

Mentoring: The award enabled Booth to mentor of one post-doctoral researcher, one graduate student, 12 undergraduate researchers, and one high-school student. Notably, of these, the post-doctoral researcher is now in an independent tenure-track position and has recently received NSF BRC-BIO funding, the graduate student has now successfully defended and has accepted a prestigious post-doctoral research position, multiple undergraduate students are now in medical or graduate school, and the high-school student is an undergraduate student. Both the post-doctoral researcher and the graduate student independently taught or co-taught undergraduate/graduate level courses. In light of the findings, Booth has recently hired a post-doctoral research associate and a graduate student to advance this research.

Outreach: Due to restrictions implemented by the global pandemic, outreach opportunities were limited. That said, Booth worked with local high-school and community college teachers to develop tuitional materials relating to mitochondrial evolution and DNA sequencing. Furthermore, the graduate student employed under this award interacted with pest-control professionals across the nation and disseminated her results relating to insecticide resistance evolution, infestation and reinfestation dynamics, and population genetic structure.

Products: This research was presented at 12 conferences, technical meetings, or invited departmental seminars. Additionally, the findings of this research were disseminated in five university undergraduate/graduate level courses. To date, results of this research have yielded eight publications and one graduate thesis.
